comments.commentBody: HILARY DID WIN the popular vote and if enough of us sign this position, we may yet get the leader we want: https://www.change.org/p/electoral-college-electors-electoral-college-ma...

"Mr. Modi may have a track record of substantial ethnic prejudice, but Donald Trump does not. And his actions to exacerbate resentment were AT LEAST equaled by Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren."

Richard - classic trumpian tactics, projecting his faults onto others. Never mind his record of racial discrimination as a landlord, he said and dog-whistled plenty in the course of his campaign.

It's no accident that he's the only major presidential candidate in my memory to be endorsed by the Klan; they know prejudice when they see it, even if you don't - or won't.

I was told men needed the better jobs and pay because they had families to support. When I think about all the overtime I worked -- without pay -- the holidays I worked covering for men with families, I realize that instead of getting .79 cents and hour on the job, I was getting paid about half that.

Another link in the chain of demagogues around the world was forged in Russia by American economists.  After the Soviet Union collapsed, Chicago-school types flooded into the country, promoting a cold shower of raw capitalism.   It was too much for the fragile democracy.  It fueled the rise of a few oligarchs (mostly former high communist officials who magically became wealthy capitalists) amid a population facing privation - conditions ripe for Putin's rise.

The disconnect between the Democratic candidate and millennials was not a product of distinct political differences, or a debate of the "lesser of two evils". The disconnect between Hillary and millennials was one of luxury. The liberal establishment was founded on intellectualism and a concern for voter issues across backgrounds. Liberal voters, when they vote, consider a range of voting issues. This voting behavior is reflected in the media. While the liberal media picked out trivial problems with Clinton's policy, conservative voters stuck to a single issue and disregarded all of Trump's other problems.

Millennials have the luxury to consider a broad range of voter issues in their own minds when they go to vote, but what does this mean for a larger voter base that might not have the luxury of intellectualism--and relies on single issues of immigration or jobs to make a decision? This election cycle proved that millennials must not only consider and debate voter issues in their own minds, but should make their political considerations public. This would promote enthusiasm among younger voters. Liberal media should change, and the liberal establishment must respond to these changes. It's time for the Democratic party and commentators to make their arguments more accessible to the public, so that their perception isn't handled or channeled by the intellectual elite. The accessibility was most appealing about Bernie's campaign--and he's right to some extent.
I am encouraging the US to build better rail service and upgrade existing lines. High speed rail would also be nice. I would like to see something like the French TGV I the US.

Are Chinese children required to take their father's name? This is the bizarre thing in the US when the woman keeps her name but her children have another last name even when she is the main caretaker or like so many, are single parents.
Children in the US are not required to take their father's name.

...because the family name was automatically assumed to be that of the father.

As it should be...what's your point?
Chinese kids can take mother's surname, most obviously in the case of "ruzhui", as the whole purpose is to propagate the lineage of mother's family (surname).

NYT, the hatchet job you did on Bernie Sanders was a disgrace. You ignored the enthusiasm that Sanders generated among young voters and Independents, and the tens of thousands of people that attended his rallies (Clinton could not even fill a school gymnasium). You ignored that Sanders led Trump by double digits in match-ups prior to the general election, whereas Clinton's lead was only in the low single digits.

And how did Clinton's pied piper strategy (one of the WikiLeaks revelations) of elevating Trump in the primary so that Clinton would have a weak opponent for the general election turn out?

WikiLeaks also revealed that Patrick Healy, MaggIe Haberman, and others from this paper (and other outlets) allowed the Clinton campaign to EDIT THEIR ARTICLES.

Your paper, the Washington Post, CNN, MSNBC, Vox, Slate, TPM, The Daily Beast, and others were PUBLIC RELATIONS FIRMS for the Clinton campaign. Shame on all of you!

How can anyone forget or under estimate contributions of Bernie Sanders. NY Times never printed any articles stating a simple fact that this paragon of peace and honesty was a lobbyist for the gun industry whose products are the leading cause of death for black teens.
Lets not forget his vendetta against Goldman Sachs, a private bank that attracted enormous wealth from overseas clients that may have gone to European banks. Poor Hillary had to waste so much time and energy to suppress Bernie's political ambitions who would have given Trump a tsunami
pf unimaginable proportions.
Clinton has 30 years of bad ethics unfortuneately backs by a rise in power

Calm down.  What do you think Breitbart and Fox News are?  There is no line whatsoever between those "news" organizations and Trump campaign, etc.  The NYX is not in that category at all.  What they failed to do was take Trump seriously and the polls trumpeted on the front page were more likely to suppress Dem voters than put Clinton in the white house.

The young politicians are asking for independence from nonsense and human rights abuse by a one-party dictatorship.  The abuse includes the manipulation of the systems to deprive young politicians from participating in elections and holding office and the disenfranchisement of a generation of Hong Kongers in violation of an international treaty signed by the PRC.  PRC is China according to the one-party dictatorship of the CCP.  Presently it is one of the many regimes in the tortured history of China.  During the Cultural Revolution in the 1960's and 1970's it emptied out the culture of China.  In the 80's, it killed the best of the country's next generation in Tennamen Square.  It is responsible for the deaths of most Chinese in the history of the world between 1950's and 1960's.  Now it tries to manipulate the electoral and judicial systems in HK in violation of an international agreement.  Otherwise they said they are afraid of a civil war.  They are also paying for tourists and locals in HK to attend their anti-independence rally organized by them.  One thing is sure: this one-party dictatorship needs prayers for all eternity to be saved, and the world with it.  In this year of mercy, let us pray for mercy for the CCP and the PRC.  May the Holy Spirit guide the young politicians of HK and bless and protect them in their service to the HK people as it does for politicians of All Nations.

So the opinion of "Zhang Rongli, a law professor at China Women’s University" is accorded the same weight as "A commenter identified as Mu Qing Shan on Baidu Feminism Tieba, a social media site," who "did not respond to attempts to contact her"?

Kids generally take their father's surname but sometimes take their mother's surname if the mother has no brothers and so there is no one else to carry on the surname of the mother.

I know it seems strange to have a mother having a different last name than her children but in China it's the norm so no one expects to see mothers with the same surname as their children. People generally refer to the mother and father as the parents of 'child's name.' There's no occasion where you'd need to refer to the "family surname."

Easy as this Monday puzzle was, I still needed two lookups: NxN’s: C at DCON/DCUNIVERSE and K at KARTS/KENNY G.

PEARL BUCK was going to be a gimme before I noticed that she was a letter short. I realized that it must be her middle initial, which was supplied by SEGO.

Possibly other times rather than other places, Martin. I read The Good Earth as an early teen-ager in the U.S., soon after it was published, and did not remember the middle initial.
It seems that back then I was not the only one.
See e.g.
http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1938/buck-bi...

I'm in the plain PEARL BUCK crowd too, and I paused over that answer for a moment.

I didn't have any trouble remembering what it was so I guess it's familiar either way, but I wasn't expecting it.

Count me as one who remembers her with the middle initial.

I read "The Good Earth" probably when I was about 10 or 12 years old, which was a looooong time ago. I don't remember a thing about it. But OLAN was a staple of XWPs for a very long time, which kept PSB top-of-mind longer than her book did.

Oddly enough, I don't think I've ever heard her referred to as "Pearl Buck." It's always "Pearl S. Buck."

I guess that's not the same in other places.

mancuroc:

David Duke and the KKK's official newspaper endorsed Trump, but Ku Klux Klan Grand Dragon Will Quigg Endorsed Hillary Clinton for President back in March. Even odder, the NAACP endorsed George Wallace back in the day.

The Klan endorsed Reagan in 1980 and 1984, who issued a dramatic condemnation of them each time (as Trump should now). But, then, Robert Byrd, the storied Democratic senator from WV was a former Klan member and served until 2010 -- he died as president pro tem of the U.S. Senate.

Any prejudice Trump holds is passive and generational -- as a GENERAL manner, he's not into identity politics. But to a lot on the left, those who don't spend every waking moment thinking about Christ risen aren't Christians.

While Trump is the flavor the month, he really has nothing to do with the French election. Le Pen's embrace of Trump is a negative for her, as Trump is likely to have an approval rating under 20% among the French.

Sarkozy will not win the right's Presidential primary. Fillon might but is a long-shot. So let's settle on Juppé as the likely choice at this moment. Then it will be Juppé vs Le Pen facing each other in the second-round of the Presidential election.

Juppé is running a socially inclusive campaign with a right-wing economic program. If he ran a typical campaign - complaining about unemployment and offering ideas how to improve it - he would trounce Le Pen badly, probably 65% to 35%. This is patly because the vast majority of the French prefer Juppé's vision of French society to Le Pen's. It is also because the rest of Le Pen's program is anti-Eu and anti-euro, and the French public is attached to the EU and the euro.

But Juppé is not running the typical campaign. He has said that he will take his election as a mandate for his program, which includes raising the retirement age to 70, a very unpopular measure. If Le Pen can transform the election into a referendum on his program, if she can convince the electorate that voting for her is a "no" vote on Juppé's economic program and not a "yes" vote for her own, then she has a good chance of winning.

Paul believes that cancer is inevitable, but it’ll be fine because it’s the slow-growing kind.

For those here who retain some open-mindedness, let me set forth what I hope he accomplishes and what the Republican Party should become under his prods.

Americans don’t have a “right” to comprehensive healthcare, but the likelihood is high that sooner or later a still-prosperous society will be forced to recognize a right to BASIC healthcare for all Americans, and the chance to affordably buy more. I hope that Trump names a two-year commission to do the hard work that Dems failed to do successfully to define, once and for all, government’s involvement in the provision of healthcare in America, and that part of its implementation will be to retire EVERY ONE of our current healthcare programs.

I hope he secures our borders and improves our domestic security by being rational about real threats to our culture, our prosperity and our very lives; but that he does it in a manner that minimizes ethnic stresses. I hope his views on “law and order” are tempered by an understanding of the racism that still pervades our society. I hope he nominates federal judges and justices who are strict constructionists but who view governance secularly; and who do NOT threaten Roe. I hope that he is judicious in his use of global force, and that he can move the free world to greater self-sufficiency in this regard while remaining the defender of last resort protecting western values and liberty.
actually they got around the all men are created equal thing  by saying that black men  were only 4/5s of a human being...... not sure what they thought of black women,
@ david..... sure those jobs will come back.... as long as you don't mind working for the same wage as they do in china.
@Richard:  Agree with you, and now women will be paying HIS debts with THEIR bodies (as they always have).

I hope that he rolls back excessive regulation and reduces taxes: this would create incentives to unleash $20-$30 trillion of corporate cash and facilitate small business success, jump-start our growth, create good jobs, increase wages and provide the means to solve OTHER immense challenges, such as climate change and dreadful education in our poorest communities. I don’t believe he’ll damage trade.

And I hope he evangelizes to business leaders that the inequalities increasingly separating Americans constitute a social time bomb that could precipitate reactions destroying ALL vestiges of American liberty. Pay your workers the maximum that their jobs are worth to your success, do not seek the extra dollar of profit at the risk of destroying the fabric of our society, and accept it as a mission as important as profit to keep America strong. We cannot become a land of 10% “winners” and 90% “losers” – not and also survive.

If Trump accomplishes all this, he could do what Mrs. Clinton hadn’t a prayer of doing with this Congress – truly making “America great again”. It’s given very few human beings to save a great nation and show the way to a world rapidly approaching unsustainability. “And a [narcissistic loudmouth] shall lead them.”

The Democratic Party? That’s YOUR challenge, but unless you get on board in this epic ride in the best interests of America, what threatens is that you all will become the speakers of a dying language. It’s happening now as we all sadly watch.

America was founded on the practice of racism, through slavery. As time went on and slavery was no longer feasible, the law and the practice morphed, but without acknowledging a grave sin or atoning for it. America is still racist today. America's elite still takes advantage of those it calls its own. With that as the foundation of my comment, here is the rest... Both campaigns used racial divide and conquer tactics, each no less ugly than the other. The media, instead of just reporting the facts, amplified those tactics and aided and abetted the campaigns, deepening the divisions in ways we can't imagine. As Trump is about to take power, who will start putting the genie back in the bottle? Hillary Clinton focused her campaign on white upper middle class female voters, to the exclusion of everyone else. When police brutality hit in September, she went on a Black radio show to announce she maybe will speak to white people. Did she speak to white people by November 8? Nope!

It isn't Trump's rural America that failed Hillary Clinton, but Hillary Clinton's arrogant expectation that not speaking to lower middle class, blue collar, Black, white, Latino, and Asian millennials wouldn't cost her any votes. Cost, it sure did. Voters don't owe candidates a thing. They didn't owe her in 08 or now.

Whites need to join their Black brothers and sisters in the civil rights struggle. My open letter: http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2s0

JB,

Trump is all that and more. It doesn't make Clinton any different than she is, her proposals any different than they were, or what voters found out about her true intentions and statements to rich donors any less what they were. People took all that in and decided as they did.

That is the reality.

J-Law,

A majority of people wanted change. No promise of change was forthcoming. What's more, people were told to their faces that they're doing well, when they are not. This country's cities, suburbs, and rural areas are full of underemployed, homeless by the hundreds of thousands, and people living in multigenerational family arrangements and they're unhappy. You can't tell people who are hungry to close their eyes and pretend their stomachs are full. That's what happened and they rebelled.

You can blame the media and the campaign for putting out narratives that don't match with the reality millions are living.

Pew Research published two major studies in May. Jared Bernstein, VP Biden's former chief economist published many pieces on the topic. I put it all together for readers here, all linked to the original.

You are free to read and take it all in.

http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/06/profiling-the-angry-american-in-this-ne...

Map,

Don't take it from me. Read US News & World Report.

http://www.usnews.com/news/the-run-2016/articles/2016-11-11/dnc-staff-ar...

Both countries lived under British rule. Artifacts of a conquered point of view are still present in both countries. Even in simple, petty things, they can be clearly seen, like Americans' raving love of British historical TV, or Indians' exaggeration of British meanness and cursing language in cinema.

Both countries were "trained" to fear and value authoritarians. As country-wide societies, we're still generically susceptible to the shine of glitz, power, money and smack-talking, hard-eyed, bullying individuals.

I've been thinking on this issue for years. How do we turn a ship which has been on a relatively steady course for centuries?

Revolutionary strategies are only partly effective, it seems, because in using such, we take on some of the attributes of our conquerors. Once supposedly free, some of us then don conquerors' likenesses and mimic their behaviors, even to the point of having episodes of highly-violent civil strife.

It's not democracy itself that's at fault. It's what democracy originally reacted to. It's long shadows cast by past extra-regional authoritarian (and economically devasting) rule.

Only by turning around to again face those old people, by identifying and speaking of the behaviors, values, mass and private communication styles, and education that represent the conquerors' stance in present times, can we move our lives to a healthy, fully-free place.

'Twas the night before Trumpmas, when all through the house, Not a creature was stirring, not even a spouse; Reporters stood close by the chimney with care, In the vain hope that somebody smart would be there; His children were nestled all snug in their beds, While visions of Breitbart danced in their heads; When on NBC there arose such a clatter, Billy Bush sprang from his bed to see what was the matter. The Bunnies on the Mara Lago golf-course outside, Made passersby stare and surf at high tide, When, what to my wondering eyes should appear, But an Access Hollywood Bus, with a microphone to hear! With a little old driver, so lively and quick, Donald said things to make Olympia Snowe sick! His eyes didn't twinkle, his brow wore a frown, His demeanor and gestures were those of a clown. His droll little mouth was drawn up like a bow, As he began to say more things to blanch Olympia Snowe! He had a broad face and a large fat round belly, That shook just as when he repulsed Megyn Kelly. He was chubby and plump, not a jolly old elf, And I vomited and fainted, in spite of myself; A wink of his eye and a wave of his hand, Beckoned hooligans everywhere to join his band. And laying his finger aside of his nose, For publicity cameras, struck a soap-opera pose. He got back in the bus, to Arianne Zucker gave a whistle, And away they all flew like the down of a thistle. But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight, "I'll buy you a highball at Hooters tonight!"

The op-ed doesn't really make sense:

Pakistan doesn't support Kashmiri separatists. It supports those who want to give Kashmir to Pakistan. Separatists want an independent Kashmir.

What is wrong with natural resource extraction and foreign capital inflows as bases of prosperity? They do not contradict productivity gains; resources can be extracted with productive labor, and capital inflows usually buy machines that increase productivity.

I am so tired of out of touch New York Times mischaracterizing entire populations because they don't agree with the Times' warped leftist view of the world. India has more minority population than any other nation on earth and hasn't become a terrible place for them like the article suggests. I am still waiting to hear from New York Times and other such elitist media on how minorities are treated in Muslim majority nations or the Middle east! hmm. Crickets!!!! Demagoguery? New York Times just has to look in the mirror!
